title: Auditory and Vestibular Neuropathy in an Adult Patient
chief_complaint: I lost my hearing suddenly in both ears about five months ago, and I have this constant ringing. I also feel dizzy, off-balance, and sometimes have blurred vision and tingling in my face, hands, and feet.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden onset 5 months prior to evaluation.
problem_summary.course: Fluctuating hearing loss; symptoms began after an 'emotional breakdown' during a stressful life event.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Tinnitus, dizziness, imbalance, blurred vision (oscillopsia), intermittent tingling/numbness of face and extremities. History of anxiety and depression.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Significant difficulty understanding speech; generalized imbalance and unsteadiness.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking diagnosis and management for hearing loss and balance issues.

history.present_illness: 5-month history of sudden bilateral hearing loss and tinnitus. Patient reports normal hearing and balance prior to this incident.
history.otologic_history: No history of noise exposure, ear surgeries, or trauma. No known family history of hearing loss.
history.medical_psych_history: Anxiety, depression, smoker (1 pack/day). Neurotology consultation sought for concurrent numbness/tingling.
history.patient_goals: Diagnosis of hearing and balance symptoms.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral asymmetrical SNHL with poor reliability. Low-frequency loss rising to better thresholds in high frequencies (reverse slope configuration). Significant disagreement between PTA and SRT.

numeric_results.Right_Ear_Configuration: Moderate to severe SNHL at 250 Hz rising to slight loss at 8000 Hz
numeric_results.Left_Ear_Configuration: Moderate SNHL at 250 Hz rising to within normal limits at 8000 Hz

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs were significantly better than PTAs (functional/non-organic pattern or neural dyssynchrony). WRS was disproportionately poor compared to pure tone thresholds.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Consistent with normal middle ear function.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Ipsilateral and contralateral acoustic reflex thresholds were absent bilaterally.

tests.name: Otoacoustic Emissions (DPOAEs)
tests.key_findings: Robust DPOAEs present bilaterally despite 'moderate to severe' behavioral thresholds. This preserves outer hair cell function, contrasting with absent reflexes.

history.present_illness: Follow-up testing recommended due to inconsistent audiological results (mismatch between PTA, SRT, and OAEs) and reports of dizziness.
history.otologic_history: Previous findings suggestive of Auditory Neuropathy Spectrum Disorder (ANSD).
history.prior_management: Referral for ABR and Vestibular Function Testing.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: No repeatable neural responses at high intensities. Cochlear Microphonic (CM) present and reverses with polarity, confirming outer hair cell function and neural dyssynchrony consistent with ANSD.

tests.name: Vestibular Function Testing (VNG/Calorics)
tests.key_findings: Normal ocular motility. Bilaterally abnormal caloric responses indicating peripheral vestibular weakness.

tests.name: Rotational Chair (SHA)
tests.key_findings: Abnormally reduced vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) gain across multiple frequencies.

tests.name: VEMPs (cVEMP and oVEMP)
tests.key_findings: Absent bilaterally, suggesting dysfunction of both superior and inferior vestibular nerve divisions.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a classic profile of Auditory Neuropathy Spectrum Disorder (ANSD) and concurrent vestibular neuropathy. Behavioral audiometry shows a fluctuating, low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss with extremely poor word recognition that is disproportionate to pure-tone thresholds. Objective testing confirms the diagnosis: Otoacoustic emissions and Cochlear Microphonics are preserved (indicating normal outer hair cell function), while ABR neural components and acoustic reflexes are absent (indicating neural dyssynchrony). Vestibular testing reveals a bilateral peripheral vestibular weakness affecting both the superior and inferior vestibular nerves.
counseling_points: Your test results show a condition called Auditory Neuropathy Spectrum Disorder (ANSD). This means your inner ear organ is working, but the connection to the hearing nerve is not firing synchronously.
This explains why you can hear sounds (tones) but have great difficulty understanding speech clearly.
You also have weakness in the balance nerves of both ears, which explains your unsteadiness and dizziness.
Because this involves both hearing and balance nerves, we need to investigate underlying causes. We are referring you to Neurology and Genetic Counseling.
Traditional hearing aids may not provide enough clarity. We will evaluate you for a Cochlear Implant, which can often bypass the damaged nerve area.
Vestibular Rehabilitation Therapy (VRT) is recommended to help your brain compensate for the balance weakness.
notes_for_actor: Portray significant difficulty understanding speech, even when the speaker is loud. It sounds 'garbled' rather than just quiet.
You are anxious and distressed about the sudden onset of these symptoms.
When performing pure-tone audiometry, be inconsistent with your button presses (poor reliability).
Describe your dizziness not as spinning vertigo, but as a constant feeling of being off-balance, unsteady, or like the world is bobbing (oscillopsia) when you walk.
